metadata.synopsis: When a string of women in Boston start turning up dead, the police launch an investigation headed by John Bottomly (Henry Fonda). Through chance, Bottomly gets the evidence he needs to arrest Albert DeSalvo (Tony Curtis). Though DeSalvo denies having any connection to the murders at first, the police use hypnosis, pressured interrogation, and interviews with the only surviving victim (Sally Kellerman) to coax him into confessing. Still, whether he is truly guilty remains a mystery to many.

reviews: An intriguing and underrated film with a great deal to say.
An excellent movie, Curtis' best role ever as the tortured Albert DeSalvo. the documentary-style suits the film perfectly. wonderfully underplayed and suspenseful from beginning to end.
Another fascinating true-crime drama by the underestimated Richard Fleischer. A cast against type Tony Curtis is excellent as killer Albert DeSalvo.
To be avoided as surely as a stranger who appears at your door and identifies himself as a plumber whom you have not called.
The Boston Strangler requires a judgment not only on the quality of the film (very good), but also on its moral and ethical implications.
Curtis works hard to give his character some force in one of his best performances.
Pretty nasty stuff for its time.
